sent_1.text: Cognitive performance and serotonergic function in users of ecstasy .

sent_2.text: RATIONALE ( +/- ) 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine ( MDMA or ecstasy ) has been shown to cause long term damage to serotonergic cerebral neurons in animals .

sent_3.text: The neurotoxic effects in humans are less clear and little is known about the functional consequences , although some studies suggest memory impairment .

sent_4.text: Given the widespread use of MDMA , our lack of knowledge raises concerns .

sent_5.text: OBJECTIVE We investigated , in humans , the relation between past use of ecstasy and cognitive performance as well as serotonergic function .

sent_6.text: METHODS Two groups of 21 males with moderate and heavy recreational use of MDMA , respectively , and a control group of 20 males without use of MDMA were compared

entity_9.text: moderate and heavy recreational use of MDMA

sent_8.text: All were from the same subculture .

sent_9.text: Reaction time , direct recall , and recognition were assessed .

sent_10.text: Serotonergic function was measured by the neuro-endocrine response to a placebo-controlled , crossover challenge with dexfenfluramine .

sent_11.text: RESULTS Ecstasy users showed a broad pattern of statistically significant , but clinically small , impairment of memory and prolonged reaction times .

sent_12.text: Heavy users were affected stronger than moderate users .

sent_13.text: Release of cortisol but not of prolactin after dexfenfluramine administration was significantly reduced in both groups of ecstasy users compared with the controls .

entity_24.text: Release of cortisol but not of prolactin

sent_14.text: Analyses of covariance showed that likely confounding variables including recent exposure to ecstasy , psychosocial profiles and use of other drugs did not explain the differences found between the groups

sent_16.text: CONCLUSIONS These results provide further evidence that use of ecstasy may be associated with impairment of memory and of serotonergic function .

entity_29.text: impairment of memory and of serotonergic function

sent_17.text: These findings are compatible with neurotoxicity of ecstasy as shown in animals .
